awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Improved Coating Properties Using Janus Particle Additives
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project offers cost-effective, commercially scalable solutions to many long-standing challenges in the coating industry. The technology will help improve properties such as water resistance, adhesion, surface hardness, and film formation. The project is not limited to waterborne architectural coatings. It may also be applied to other coating systems, including coatings for automobiles, inks for printing, cosmetics for personal care products, and functional coatings for medical appliances. The technology can potentially increase the performance and lifetime for coatings that play a critical role in protecting various surfaces from aging or deteriorating. In addition, this effort represents a platform technology that offers a unique way to control surface properties, which may enable new designs for functional coatings, including self-cleaning and anti-bacterial coatings. The use of these new coatings may, in turn, reduce the pollution to the environment and reduce energy costs.

This I-Corps project is based on a new way of creating self-stratified coatings using amphiphilic Janus particles, where one side of the particle can resist water and the other side can be highly adhesive. Upon drying, Janus particles vigorously accumulate at the air-water interface with fast kinetics.  Their hydrophobic sides orient towards the air to enhance the water-repellency while the hydrophilic sides sustain strong adhesion with the underlying layer. This proposal explores the potential commercialization and market of such technology for creating water-resistant coatings and the broad applications of the newly developed self-stratification system. It provides potential improvements in surface properties by directly adding Janus particles without redesigning the original coating chemistries. The results will help guide future research directions of Janus particles and self-stratified coating materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
We carried more than 110 customer surveys through phone interviews, on-site visits, coating tech conferences and trade shows. Our interviews broadly covered the professionals in the coating industry, including R&D scientists, executives, quality control inspectors, local regulators, home improvement sales associates, and home painting contractors. We also met with our strategic partner, Diamond Vogel, a regional coating manufacture, and had one-on-one in-depth discussions and interviews with the executive team, including their CEO and vice president.

Below are the major outcomes of our efforts:

  1. Several key insights of coating markets were revealed through the process. Architectural coatings such as wall paints are generally considered commodities, for which coating manufacturers tend to focus mainly on ensuring quality control, complying with regulations, and maintaining the price range. As a result, investment in new technology is limited within this field. However, a major pain point brought up consistently during interviews was sustainability, and the need to shift toward water-based products to comply with regulations on VOCs - especially for specialty coatings.
  2. We identified the industry paint point. After many years of R&D and numerous trials of different chemicals and formulations, the industry still could not solve some issues for water-based coatings or stains. For example, the acceptance of water-based wood stains with DIY end-users is low.
  3. We have identified a business partner and established our startup company, Janas Materials Inc. Our company signed a work agreement with the biggest regional paint manufacturer Diamond Vogel. In addition, we have submitted an NSF-SBIR grant. We also received several grants related to our I-Corp work, including the NSF PFI-TT grant and Regents Innovation Fund.
  4. Our company developed the first MVP, a water based wood stain additive product that can help eliminate the color inconsistency issues.
  5. We participated the TechConnect conferences and pitched ideas to the audience. We also identified a new area of potential application for our technology as a PFAS replacement.
  6. Two postdocs, three graduate students, and three undergraduate students have participated the program and gained valuable experience through this project. One postdoc and one graduate student successfully interviewed and received job offers from major coating companies.
  7. We are in the process of receiving funding to collaborate on more R&D work with one of the major chemical companies.

Last Modified: 08/25/2023
Modified by: Shan Jiang
por.por_txt_cntn:
We carried more than 110 customer surveys through phone interviews, on-site visits, coating tech conferences and trade shows. Our interviews broadly covered the professionals in the coating industry, including R&D scientists, executives, quality control inspectors, local regulators, home improvement sales associates, and home painting contractors. We also met with our strategic partner, Diamond Vogel, a regional coating manufacture, and had one-on-one in-depth discussions and interviews with the executive team, including their CEO and vice president.

Below are the major outcomes of our efforts:

Several key insights of coating markets were revealed through the process. Architectural coatings such as wall paints are generally considered commodities, for which coating manufacturers tend to focus mainly on ensuring quality control, complying with regulations, and maintaining the price range. As a result, investment in new technology is limited within this field. However, a major pain point brought up consistently during interviews was sustainability, and the need to shift toward water-based products to comply with regulations on VOCs - especially for specialty coatings. 
We identified the industry paint point. After many years of R&D and numerous trials of different chemicals and formulations, the industry still could not solve some issues for water-based coatings or stains. For example, the acceptance of water-based wood stains with DIY end-users is low. 
We have identified a business partner and established our startup company, Janas Materials Inc. Our company signed a work agreement with the biggest regional paint manufacturer Diamond Vogel. In addition, we have submitted an NSF-SBIR grant. We also received several grants related to our I-Corp work, including the NSF PFI-TT grant and Regents Innovation Fund. 
Our company developed the first MVP, a water based wood stain additive product that can help eliminate the color inconsistency issues. 
We participated the TechConnect conferences and pitched ideas to the audience. We also identified a new area of potential application for our technology as a PFAS replacement. 
Two postdocs, three graduate students, and three undergraduate students have participated the program and gained valuable experience through this project. One postdoc and one graduate student successfully interviewed and received job offers from major coating companies. 
We are in the process of receiving funding to collaborate on more R&D work with one of the major chemical companies.
